comments:
Since full indexing became the default, I have created a couple different 
projects using existing code that the indexer didn't handle well. In both 
cases, the indexer created over a 3000 problems and took the javaw memory 
usage from about 100MB to 320MB. In trying to reproduce it just now, memory 
usage went to 335MB and I got an out of memory error in eclipse. 

The projects are standard make C projects. The problem reported is: C/C++ 
Indexer Problem: Preprocessor Inclusion not found: xxx.h in file: xxx.c on 
line: xx.

I am using RC3. The about menu says Version: 3.0.0 Build id: 200508081313 for 
the org.eclipse.cdt feature.

I realize the workaround is to turn indexing off. But when it is turned on but 
doesn't work, I think it should stop itself after a reasonable amount of time 
and before chewing thru the memory. I have had some cases where indexing works 
fine, so I would prefer to turn it off when necessary, or perhaps have a 
chance to fix the problem with the includes.

Depending on the size of your project, full indexing might not be the best
choice.   The CDT parser can consume a lot of memory while going through files
during an index. You can try using the CTags indexer or increasing the heap size
(when you start Eclipse pass in -Xmx512M or whatever size you want).

I meet the same trouble. I have tried CDT with a QT project and a STL project.
They are all very short test code. But eclipse still cost about 1G memory (I set
1G max memory useage limit in commandline option), and CPU useage keeping 100%.
After I turned off the indexing, everything works perfact.
So, full indexing became no use for me.

same problem here. 2x opteron 2200 (amd64), 1gb ram, gentoo. eclipse 3.1.1 and cdt 3.0.1.
log for both java 2 and java 5 below.
